art.title: Count Loop
art.description: Multiple artworks including computer-drawn images, sculptures, and music created using a defined counting pattern.
art.body: Multiple pieces manifesting the same pattern defined by a simple mathematical framework that generates complexity from the inherent qualities of integer numbers. The series invludes multiple types of artworks including computer-drawn images, sculptures, and music. The visual, physical and auditory results have common qualities and reveal concepts of number theory. In "Gradient", repeating patterns can be found at rates consistent with the least common multiple of the row numbers. These same rates can also be found in "Towers" in which tower height patterns of wooden blocks repeat. In Note Scale, note patterns repeat at set rates for the duration of the piece. When installed, the pieces collectively span one pattern loop which transitions from one medium to the next.

images.title: Count Loop: Gradient
images.caption: 2013 / video

images.title: Count Loop: Towers
images.caption: 2013 / 20x100 in / sculpture

images.title: Count Loop: Note Scale
images.caption: 2013 / sound installation

art.title: Me Trying to Disappear
art.description: Video and installation works exploring the nature of existence and non-existence through various forms of failed disappearance.
art.body: A series of video and installations exploring the nature of existence and non-existence. In the pieces, various forms of failed disappearance are attempted: from sitting still for a program to mask the bits of a sitter's image in front of the camera to a set of positive and negative images attempting to cancel each other out, to a runner trying to run fast enough to pass through the frame without being caught by the camera. In trying to avoid representation and thus disappear, the subject represented plays with the notion of reality and presence.

images.title: Me Trying to Disappear 2: Still
images.caption: 2013 / 20x24 in / video

images.title: Me Trying to Disappear 3: Plus Minus
images.caption: 2013 / 20x24 in / video installation

art.title: Construct
art.description: A commissioned show documenting the construction of Milstein Hall from the perspective of a student.
art.body:
Construct was a show for which Michelle Chen and I were commissioned as Fine Arts students by the Dean of the College of Architecture, Art and Planning at Cornell University. The purpose of the project was to document the construction of Milstein Hall, the new building for the School of Architecture, from the perspective of a student and to think about what this building could mean to those who would inhabit it. This was the first show installed in the Milstein Hall Gallery when the building opened.

As a part of this show I created a series of photographs overlaying images of the AAP campus taken by students from the early 19th century, with contemporary images at the exact same locations during the construction of Milstein Hall. In this way the past and present were forced into interaction, each at transformational moments, creating an anachronistic space in which the past and present can talk and reveal their similarities and differences.

In another series of photographs I overlaid images of different rooms at various stages of the building's construction. This was done by creating digital prints of the images on clear film and framing them together, but separating them with pieces of plexiglass to create an image that was physically layered creating a sense of stacked but distinguishable moments in time.

art.title: Discrete Nature
art.description: Works exploring the role of computation, order and randomness in the process of creation.
art.body: Sculptures containing unique images created using a MATLAB program that generates figures using a given set of rules and random numbers. The creation of these images utilizes both order and randomness in the process of creation to create families of related images. The pieces involve the role of computation as a tool for direct or indirect creation and the exploration of what is authored and what is not, of what is fabricated and what is natural.

images.caption: 2009 / 12x12x3 in / corrugated plastic, digital transparent print

images.caption: 2009 / 5x5x3 in / corrugated plastic, threaded rods, digital transparent prints

tech.title: Epicyclificator
tech.description: A Python script that takes an SVG file and produces a GIF animation of epicycles approximating each closed curve in the SVG.
tech.body: The epicyclificator is a python script that calculates epicycle approximations of arbitrary closed curves to create epicycle animations that "illustrate" and "erase" any input drawing. This is achieved by taking in svg drawings, calculating an epicycle approximation for each closed curve and generating a gif animation of the epicycle motions. You can see how this works in the README and the script in my github repo: epicycles

images.title: Car
images.caption: 2019 / Epicycle approximation of a car outline

images.caption: 2019 / Epicycle approximation of cactus flowers

tech.title: Autonomous Bicycle
tech.description: A self-stabilizing bicycle developed at Andy Ruina's Robotics Lab at Cornell University.
tech.body:
Understanding human balance is an important endeavor both for the advancement of medical understanding and for expanding the capabilities of future robotic systems. Towards this end, the Biorobotics and Locomotion Laboratory started the Autonomous Bicycle project with the goal of developing a self-stabilizing bicycle that could be made into a stable drive by wire vehicle for a rider, or into a completely autonomous system with either remote or onboard navigation. This project has the potential for a multiplicity of benefits like enabling research on balance by logging human actions when riding the bicycle, creating safe bicycles that will stabilize on their own for riders who are unable to do so, or creating fully autonomous systems that can perform tasks.

In the Spring of 2014 I joined the research team and developed a reference-tracking observer-based controller for the self-stabilizing bicycle using the CVX optimization package in MATLAB. I also built a simulator using ODE45 and an animating function to plot the solution of the bicycle using the developed controller. This design showed promise in simulation and was ready for implementation on a real bicycle.

Apart from working on the controls, I also helped in the construction of the electrical components, actuators, and some preliminary code needed to build the final system. This involved the integration of a hub motor, a servo-motor, motor-drivers, an IMU, a BeagleBone Black microcontroller and other circuits necessary for these components to communicate.

images.caption: 2014 / Developed at Andy Ruina's Robotics Lab at Cornell University / Above is the simulated bicycle controlling the steer angle to a reference and maintaining the bicycle upright

tech.title: Dune Bot
tech.description: A non-holonomic modular robotics platform developed at Cornell Cup Lab for outdoor data collection and human-robot games.
tech.body:
The Dune Bot was developed in the Cornell Cup Lab as a non-holonomic modular robotics platform which would enable various research teams to adapt its capabilities as a robust vehicle with other added functionality for uses such as outdoor data collection or even game play in a human-robot game of laser tag.

I worked on this project in the Fall of 2012 and became the Mechanical Engineering team lead in the Spring of 2013. I worked with team mates on the high-level design of the system and integration of the various components as well as performing critical analyses of the design feasibility and helped manufacture and assemble the system. The robot was showcased at the 2013 Cornell Cup at Disney World.

images.title: Dune Bot
images.caption: 2013 / Developed with Cornell Cup Lab at Cornell University / Above is the Dune Bot prototype with all driving motors, suspension and steering servos mounted

images.title: Dune Bot
images.caption: 2013 / Developed with Cornell Cup Lab at Cornell University / Above is the Dune Bot prototype with all electronics mounted and a laser tag gun turret mounted on top

tech.title: Mod Bot Launcher
tech.description: A racquetball launcher designed for a holonomic modular robotics platform to enable robots to catch and throw.
tech.body:
The Mod Bot was developed in the Cornell Cup Lab as a holonomic modular robotics platform with overhead camera localization and a model-predictive controller for the development of new autonomous systems by various research teams. One particular goal of this system was to enable the creation of multiple robots with the ability to catch and throw racquetballs to play a game of catch.

I joined the team in the Spring of 2012 and worked on various aspects of the robot. For one of the components of this system, I designed, built and tested a racquetball launcher to be incorporated into the juggling system. The design was developed in Solid Works, was built using a laser cutter and a machine shop, and was tested at our lab.
